abstract.text: Update your code to make use of the new capabilities of the
macro, including automatic
fulfillment of requirements for destination reducers and path reducers.

inlineContent.text: The Composable Architecture is under constant development, and we are always looking for ways to
simplify the library, and make it more powerful. This version of the library only introduced new
APIs and did not deprecate any existing APIs. However, to make use of these tools your features
must already be integrated with the
macro from version 1.4. See
for more information.
The
macro is now capable of automatically filling in the
protocol’s
requirements for you. For example, even something as simple as this:
…now compiles.
The
macro will automatically insert an empty
struct, an empty
enum, and an empty
. This effectively means that
is a logicless, behaviorless, inert reducer.
Having these requirements automatically fulfilled for you can be handy for slowly
filling them in with their real implementations. For example, this
reducer could be
integrated in a parent domain using the library’s navigation tools, all without having implemented
any of the domain yet. Then, once we are ready we can start implementing the real logic and
behavior of the feature.
There is a common pattern in the Composable Architecture of representing destinations a feature
can navigate to as a reducer that operates on enum state, with a case for each feature that can
be navigated to. This is explained in great detail in the
and
articles.
This form of domain modeling can be very powerful, but also incur a bit of boilerplate. For example,
if a feature can navigate to 3 other features, then one might have a
reducer like
the following:
It’s not the worst code in the world, but it is 24 lines with a lot of repetition, and if we need
to add a new destination we must add a case to the
enum, a case to the
enum, and a
to the
The
macro is now capable of generating all of this code for you from the following
simple declaration:
24 lines of code has become 6. The
macro can now be applied to an
enum
where each
case holds onto the reducer that governs the logic and behavior for that case.
If the parent feature has equatable state, you must extend the generated
of the
enum reducer to be
as well. Due to a bug in Swift 5.9 that prevents this from being
done in the same file with an explicit extension, we provide the following configuration options,
, instead, which can be told which synthesized conformances to apply:
Further, when using the
operator with this style of
enum
reducer you can completely leave off the trailing closure as it can be automatically inferred:
The same simplifications can be made to
reducers when using navigation stacks, as detailed
in
. However, there is an additional super power that comes with
to further simplify constructing navigation stacks.
Typically in stack-based applications you would model a single
reducer that encapsulates all
of the logic and behavior for each screen that can be pushed onto the stack. This can now be done
in a super concise syntax thanks to the new powers of
And in this case you can now leave off the trailing closure of the
operator:
But there’s another part to path reducers that can also be simplified. When constructing the
we need to specify a trailing closure that switches on the
enum
and decides what view to drill-down to. Currently it can be quite verbose to do this:
This requires a two-step process of first destructuring the
enum to figure out which
case the state is in, and then further scoping the store down to a particular case of the
enum. And since such extraction is failable, we have to
unwrap the scoped
store, and only then can we pass it to the child view being navigated to.
The new super powers of the
macro greatly improve this code. The macro adds a
computed property to the store so that you can switch on the
enum
and
extract out a store in one step:
This is far simpler, and comes for free when using the
macro on your enum
reducers.

abstract.text: A destructurable view of a store on a collection of cases.
Update your code to make use of the new
operation on
in order to improve the performance of your features and simplify the usage of navigation APIs.
The Sharing library has graduated, with backwards-incompatible changes, to 2.0, and the Composable
Architecture has been updated to extend support to this new version.
A Composable Architecture-friendly wrapper around
that simplifies working with
collections of state.
Update your code to make use of the new observation tools in the library and get rid of legacy
APIs such as
, and more.
The library has been completely updated for Swift 6 language mode, and now compiles in strict
concurrency with no warnings or errors.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain.
The content and behavior of a reducer that is composed from other reducers.
Learn how to upgrade your application to the newest version of the Composable Architecture.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
Store internals have been rewritten for performance and future features, and are now compatible with
SwiftUI’s
property wrapper.
Update your code to use the new
method for mutating shared state from asynchronous
contexts, rather than mutating the underlying wrapped value directly.
A special overload of
for enum
reducers.
A special overload of
for enum
reducers.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on an optional property of parent state.
The Composable Architecture now provides first class tools for building features in UIKit,
including minimal state observation, presentation and stack navigation.
Places a value in the reducer’s dependencies.
A view helper that transforms a
into a
so that its state can be observed
by a view builder.
Update your code to make use of the new
method on
which gives a succinct syntax for sending actions with case key paths, and
the
method for overriding dependencies.
Learn about stack-based navigation, that is navigation modeled with collections, including how to
model your domains, how to integrate features, how to test your features, and more.
Helps implement the conformance to the
protocol for a type.
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
Stores now automatically cancel their in-flight effects when they deallocate. And another UIKit
navigation helper has been introduced.
A type that holds the current state of the reducer.
The
property wrapper and related tools have been extracted to their own
library so that they can be used in non-Composable Architecture applications. This a
backwards compatible change, but some new deprecations have been introduced.
Update your code to make use of the new state sharing tools in the library, such as the
property wrapper, and the
and
persistence strategies.
Take advantage of custom decoding and encoding logic for the shared file storage persistence
strategy, as well as beta support for Swift’s native Testing framework.
Update your code to make use of the
macro, and learn how to better leverage case key
paths in your features.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on elements of a navigation stack in
parent state.
An overload of
that takes a description of protocol conformances to synthesize on
the State and Action types
A testable runtime for a reducer.
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
A type that holds all possible actions that cause the
of the reducer to change
and/or kick off a side
that can communicate with the outside world.
A view that safely unwraps a store of optional state in order to show one of two views.
The
strategy used with
now uses key-value observing instead of
when possible. Learn how this may affect your code.
Update your code to make use of the new
method when you need to
assert on the payload inside an action received.
The
type is now officially
isolated.
Learn about tree-based navigation, that is navigation modeled with optionals and enums, including
how to model your domains, how to integrate features, how to test your features, and more.
Scopes the store to one that exposes child state and actions.
